results.title: Human development: conception to neonate. Birth and the newborn
results.brief_description: Begins by contrasting today’s birth experience with that of 30 years ago. Describes family sensitive birth practices and initial interactions between parents and newborn. Discusses the physical care of the neonate immediately after birth. Describes common characteristics of the neonate including fontanelles and innate reflexes.

results.title: Human beginnings
results.creator_credit: Eddie Albert Productions and University of Oregon
results.brief_description: The film opens showing a class of six-year-old boys and girls working out, through drawing and clay models, their ideas of how a baby grows inside its mother. Each child holds up their drawing and explains to the others what it means to them. The film indicates that all the children have a sound basic idea about human growth and the value of discussion with caring adults.

results.title: Human and animal beginnings. - 2nd ed.
results.brief_description: Uses the reproduction of small animals to introduce children to human reproduction. Emphasises the role of families in caring for the newborn. Suitable for primary level.

results.title: Human and animal beginnings
results.creator_credit: Wexler Film Productions and Curtis Avery
results.brief_description: Presents basic information about human reproduction and concepts of the family. Includes baby monkeys and mice, newborn guinea pigs and rabbits, with time-lapse photography of a hatching chicken egg and fish eggs. Animated sequences showing prebirth growth and development, and birth itself. Also shows scenes of babies in the hospital nursery home.

results.title: Human aggression (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Follows the activities of a youth gang, showing how aggression is used to assert dominance and territoriality; is provoked by frustration; and is displaced onto others. The frustration-aggression hypothesis is discussed and demonstrated in a laboratory experiment. Modifications to the hypothesis point to frustration as a key element in provoking aggression. Considers the importance of the psychological training of police who intervene in aggressive disputes.

results.title: Hullabaloo over Georgie & Bonnie's pictures
results.creator_credit: Merchant Ivory Productions, London Weekend Television, Ismail Merchant and James Ivory
results.brief_description: The “hullaballo” in question is a leisurely, but fiercely determined race for possession of a priceless collection of rare Indian pictures. It’s enlivened by a romp through royal India…a world of princes, palaces, tourists, precious art objects and their wheelers and dealers… but more than this, the film gives us rare insight into the lasting values of life. The films boasts a wonderful screenplay by Ruth Prawer Jhabuala. Stars Peggy Ashcroft.

results.title: Hug me
results.creator_credit: Bosustow Entertainment, Churchill Films, Nick Bosustow and Sam Weiss
results.brief_description: An animated story of a lonely porcupine who wants a friend to hug him more than anything else in the world, but who is shunned by the other animals. He eventually finds such a friend in the forest. Based on the book “Hug me” by Patti Stren.

results.title: Huey Long
results.creator_credit: Sterling Productions, Walter Reade and David L. Wolper
results.brief_description: A biographical film on the life of Louisianna’s infamous governor Huey Long. Using photographs and archival footage, this documentary focuses on his political career as Railroad Commisioner, Governor of Louisianna and US Senator and touches on his aspirations for the US presidency. Promoting himself as an enemy of large corporations and a champion of the ‘common man’ his social platform revolved around public works programmes and social services. Allegations of bribery and corruption instigated actions to remove him from local and national politicals. Long was assasinated in 1935 by Carl White, a young doctor who’s family had been persecuted by Long. The archival film that was sourced for this documentary include footage of Mardi Gas and jazz scenes of New Orleans in the 20’s; armed police supporting Huey Long; Louisianna’s political heavyweights during Long’s reign; and a memorable performance by Huey Long singing his election song ‘Everyman a king’. Commentary by Mike Wallace.

results.title: Hudson 70
results.brief_description: The circumnavigation of the continents of North and South America, for long a navigator’s dream, was accomplished in 1970 by the Canadian Scientific Ship “Hudson” as part of Canada’s commitment to the International Oceanographic Decade, a project of UNESCO. Here is the ship’s log, detailing the many kinds of research in which the “Hudson” engaged. The last phase of the 47,000 mile voyage documented, for the first time, scientific investigations of the polar seas above Canada.

results.title: Hud
results.brief_description: Based on Larry McMurtry’s novel about the experiences of a young boy growing up in Texas, “Hud” is a powerful story of family corruption and betrayal. Lone (Brandon de Wilde) is a teenager in a sleepy Texas town whose hero is his cavalier uncle, Hud (Paul Newman). Hud is the new face of the West. Unlike his father he refuses traditional values based on hard work and community and instead stands for a new creed of economic selfishness and sexual amorality. Hud’s bitter relationship with his father (Melvyn Douglas) comes to a head when a mysterious illness starts attacking their cattle. As the two men fight it out, Lone has to choose between the two men and decide for himself what kind of man he wishes to become. The makers of “Hud”, many of whom were blacklisted in the 1950s, have lovingly recreated the bleakness and beauty of a desert community. They have also created one of the first modern westerns, a film which challenges the myths of the Wild West and instead powerfully examines the reality of social, economic and gender relationships in rural America. The stunning black and white photography is by acclaimed cinematographer James Wong Howe and the music score is by Elmer Bernstein. Melvyn Douglas won an Academy Award for his performance, as did Patricia Neal, who as the divorcee housekeeper who knows her time and her looks are fading, gives one of the great performances of the 1960s.
